frameDefinitions: A Mass_theme, generally made up of many individuals, moves from a Source to a Goal with some Path.
A Protagonist delays a planned action because they cannot or do not want to proceed until an Expected_event occurs.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
A Trajector is identified as occurring at the same time as some better-known Landmark.
These words relate to the relative ordering of two events or times.
An Agent decides temporarily not to perform a Desirable_action or not to interact with a Salient_entity.
frameExamples: Emails from so-called Nigerian princes <t>flooded</t> inboxes all over the US.
The cat <t>waited</t> on top of the washer as Elmer popped the lid off the can of cat food and then pounded the can's contents onto the plate
He tried to take care of that <t>on</t> his last visit .
<t>After</t> she arrived , she laid out her papers on the desk.
I have actually <t>held off</t> on buying some movies by WB because of those damned cases.
listRoleDefinitions: The mass of entities which moves.
The place where the overall motion event takes place, thus including Source, Path, and Goal locations.
The Source is the location the Theme occupies initially before its change of location.
Path refers to (a part of the) ground the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> travels over or to a landmark the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> travels by.
Goal is the location the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> ends up in.

This role is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the <fen>Goal</fen> of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often <fen>Direction</fen> is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the <fen>Mass_theme</fen>, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
When the event occurs.
The spatial setting in which the Mass_motion takes place.
The sentient being who cannot proceed with their planned activities until a Salient_entity has arrived or an Expected_event has occurred.
A concrete or abstract entity that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> expects to participate in an <fen>Expected_event</fen>, typically that of arriving at the <fen>Place</fen> of the <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
The <fen>Expected_event</fen> is an event that needs to take place or a state that needs to begin to hold before the <fen>Protagonist</fen> can proceed with their planned activities.
The time period during which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
The location in which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.

This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The entity that occurs at some time.
The event which designates the time at which a trajector occurs.
The period that occurs with respect to some other time.
The period in which a trajector takes place.  This period can be cyclical and, in that case, is interpreted contextually.
The event that occurs at some time.
The entity which designates the time of some trajector.  Note: this role is infrequent or non-existent in English and is included for completeness.

The <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is the event which is  being located in time with respect to some other event: The <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is profiled, in contrast to the <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen>, which is backgrounded.
The <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen> is the event  with respect to which the <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is located.
The <fen>Focal_participant</fen> is the participant in the <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> which is profiled as being in a relation of relative time to the <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> decides not to engage in a <fen>Desirable_action</fen> for a while or not to interact with a <fen>Salient_entity</fen>.
<fen>Desirable_action</fen> identifies the event or activity in which the <fen>Agent</fen> does not engage for a while.
An entity that evokes a contextually inferrable <fen>Desirable_action</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> is temporarily forgoing.
This role identifies the interval of <fen>Time</fen> during which the the forgoing occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the temporary forgoing occurs.
listRoleExamples: Letters streamed in <fex>all over the country</fex>.
Afterwards, the crowd flooded <fex>away from the ceremony</fex>.
The door opened , and a crowd of people flooded <fex>past me</fex>, into the hall.
Eager spectators crowded <fex>into the auditorium</fex>
<fex>In the main auditorium</fex> people crowded around Orange's newest computer
<fex>He</fex> politely waited, hat in hand, until he could speak.
In busier times several passengers are waiting <fex>for the train</fex>.
She did n't wait <fex>for a reply</fex>, but spelled out the answer herself.
At least 17 ships were waiting <fex>yesterday</fex> to come up the river.
Reporters are waiting <fex>outside the State Guesthouse</fex> for the talks to start .
Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
The current <fex>President of Georgia</fex> was born in Tbilisi.
During <fex>last night's walk</fex> , I stubbed my toe.
Future <fex>eras</fex> will be vastly changed from today.
I went to the store on <fex>Tuesday</fex>.
Currently, <fex>researchers are making new discoveries very quickly.</fex>
<fex>Hours of eating and drinking</fex> followed the wedding ceremony.
Hours of eating and drinking followed <fex>the wedding ceremony</fex>.
<fex>We</fex> were late for dinner.
Instead, <fex>he</fex> held off on a public announcement of his decision for more than a year.
The board also waited <fex>with the appointment of seven members to the planning and zoning commission</fex> until a policy is set regarding requirements.
I ordered the blackberry cobbler with ice cream for dessert and held off <fex>on another pint</fex> as the rain kept coming down.

Saskatchewan teachers are not a happy lot as they had voted for a strike in June
<fex>then</fex> held off on it to give negotiations a chance during the summer.
